Scam Warnings

Protect yourself from common sailboat buying and selling scams.

‚ö†Ô∏è Stay Alert

Unfortunately, scammers target boat buyers and sellers. If a deal seems too good to be true, it probably is. Always verify before sending money.

Common Scam Red Flags

Price is Too Low

A boat priced significantly below market value is often a scam. Research fair prices in our photo gallery.

Seller is "Out of Town"

Scammers claim they can't meet in person. They're military, missionaries, or recently relocated.

Requests Wire Transfer or Gift Cards

Legitimate sellers accept normal payment methods. Wire transfers and gift cards cannot be reversed.

Uses an "Escrow" Service You've Never Heard Of

Fake escrow websites are common. Only use well-known services and verify independently.

Pressure to Act Fast

Scammers create urgency. A legitimate seller will give you time to verify.

How to Protect Yourself

  • See the boat in person before sending any money
  • Verify ownership - check the title and registration
  • Meet at the boat's location - don't have it "shipped" to you
  • Use secure payment - cash at closing, cashier's check, or known escrow
  • Research the seller - search their email and phone online
  • Trust your instincts - if something feels wrong, walk away

Report a Scam

If you encounter a scam or suspicious listing, please let us know so we can warn others.

Report to Sailing Texas

You can also report to the FBI's Internet Crime Complaint Center.

More Information

Read detailed scam examples and warnings on our legacy site.
